Black holes are formed when super massive stars die. To understand how a black hole is formed we first need to understand how a star takes birth, transforms and eventually dies out leading to the formation of a black hole. We know that Hydrogen is the most abundant element in the universe and so large clouds of hydrogen and dust are randomly scattered across galaxies. It all starts when huge clouds of Hydrogen, other gases and dust particles come together. Stellar Nebula:  When this collection of gas and dust, referred to as a Stellar Nebula, is massive enough its own gravity causes it to collapse, it starts to fall in on itself and towards the center it starts getting denser and hotter. This center is the energy source and thus a new star is born. Protostar These newly formed stars are called Protostars. The core of the star continues to fall inward and the hot center starts giving out light and the star begins to shine. When atoms come closer and closer under gravitational pull, they come so close that the Hydrogen atoms start getting fused into each other to form Helium, a process that release huge amounts of energy.  At this point the energy being produces by these fusion reactions will be countered by the inward gravitational pull of the center. This is where the size of the star decides its fate. The smallest amount of mass required to sustain this state as a star is referred to as one solar mass, which is the equivalent of our own sun’s mass. The larger the mass the more fuel a star has at its core and the higher the amount of energy produced from fusions. Slowly the fuel in the core, which is Hydrogen, starts running out. As the core becomes smaller and smaller it gets hotter and more energy is produced, this energy will start getting stronger than inward gravitational pull and eventually starts pushing the outer limits of the start outward. Red Giant  As a result of the rapid expansion the outer shell starts cooling, giving out a red haze. In this stage the star is called a Red Giant. When all the Hydrogen atoms fuse to become Helium the core runs out of fuel and the energy from fusion reactions starts getting lesser and lesser. At this stage the gravity takes over and starts crushing the core with even grater force. This immense pressure causes the Helium atoms to start fusing with each other forming heavier elements like Carbon, Iron, Silicon and releasing even higher amount of energy as compared to energy released from Hydrogen fusions. Supernova  By the time the star runs out of fuel again it is left a relatively stable core made up of these heavier elements. Because of lesser and lesser energy pushing the core outward gravity wins the fight and crushes the core instantaneously resulting in the outer layers bouncing off the core in a super intense explosion called a Supernova. The blast is so intense that it spits out the star’s guts to large distances throwing away most of the elements formed in the process. The super hot explosion forms most of the elements we find in the in the universe such as Cobalt, Nickel, Copper. The rapidly spreading super hot material will form a Planetary Nebula and can be observed from earth. Some examples of this are the Cat’s Eye Nebula, Crab Nebula.  White Dwarf After the Supernova explosion, the star’s core is left with relatively stable heavier elements, in other words it is one big metallic solid, called White Dwarf . At this stage most stars do not have enough mass to cause their gravity to push further inward, so they burn out for a few million years and dies out a peaceful death. This is not the case for super massive starts, if the left over core’s mass is higher than 1.4 times the solar mass (knows as Chandrashekar limit), the core will again be subjected to intense gravitational crush. Neutron Star  If the star is between 1.4 to 3 times the solar mass the inward gravity causes all the electrons to fuse with protons and form neutrons. . The electron and proton fusions release such a huge amount of energy that another supernova explosion occurs and eventually all that is left is a core entirely made up of neutrons. Singularity By this time the initial super massive star which was thousands of light years across is reduced into a super dense glob of neutrons the size of just a few thousand kilometers. If the white dwarf before the explosion is of a mass greater than 3 solar masses ( meaning the original star had a mass of 10 to 80 solar masses ) , the gravity is still so powerful that it over comes the repulsion between the tightly packed neutrons (neutron degeneracy pressure) and crushes the core into a single point of infinite density forming a black hole!  Black holes as we know them are not that common because at any of the above mentioned stages the end result could be different based on the mass of the original star. Hope this helps. A slightly different kind of supernova explosion occurs when even larger, hotter stars (blue giants and blue supergiants) reach the end of their short, dramatic lives. These stars are hot enough to burn not just hydrogen and helium as fuel, but also carbon, oxygen and silicon. Eventually, the fusion in these stars forms the element iron (which is the most stable of all nuclei, and will not easily fuse into heavier elements), which effectively ends the nuclear fusion process within the star. Lacking fuel for fusion, the temperature of the star decreases and the rate of collapse due to gravity increases, until it collapse completely on itself, blowing out material in a massive supernova explosion. If the mass of the compressed remnant of the star exceeds about 3 - 4 solar masses, then even the degeneracy pressure of neutrons is insufficient to halt the collapse and, instead of forming a neutron star, the core collapses completely into a gravitational singularity, a single point containing all the mass of the entire original star. The gravity in such a phenomenon is so strong that it overwhelms all other forces, to the extent that even light can not escape from it, hence the name black hole. Thus, the gravity of a body just a few times denser than a neutron star would result in its inevitable further collapse into a black hole.  Simulated black hole in front of the Milky Way  Although singularity at the the centre of a black hole is infinitely dense, the black hole itself is not necessarily huge, as is sometimes assumed. A black hole with the mass of our Sun, for example, would have a radius of just three kilometres (roughly two hundred million times smaller than the Sun), while one with the mass of the Earth would fit in the palm of your hand! Having said that, black holes can grow to great size over time as they assimilate more and more matter and even other black holes, and some do become extremely massive. Contrary to popular belief, a black hole does not just "suck up" everything around it in an uncontrolled orgy of destruction: it actually exerts no more gravitational pull on the objects around it than the original star from which it was formed, and any objects orbiting the original star (and which survived the supernova blast) would now orbit a black hole instead (an object would need to approach quite close to a black hole before being sucked in). The very largest blue stars may skip even the supernova stage, so that even their outer shells become incorporated into the singularity. By definition, we cannot observe black holes directly, but they can be detected by the gravitational effect they exert on other bodies or on light rays. This is especially easy to spot in the case of binary star systems where an ordinary star is orbiting around a black hole. In the early 1990s, Reinhard Genzel pioneered this work, using the then new technique of adaptive optics to plot and track the motions of stars near the centre of our own Milky Way galaxy, to show that they must be orbiting a very massive, but invisible, object. From the immense speed with which the stars closest to the centre of the galaxy are orbiting - millions of kilometeres per hour - we know that there is a "supermassive black hole" (known as Sagittarius A) at the centre of the Milky Way, with a mass of around 2 - 4 million times that of our Sun. In addition, in the Milky Way galaxy alone, there are many millions of black holes of at least ten solar masses each. Supermassive black holes lurk in the centres of most galaxies, forming the hubs around which the galaxies rotate. In fact, from observations of the intense radiation of gases swirling around them at close to the speed of light, we can infer that there are much larger supermassive black holes in the centres of other galaxies, some of them weighing as much as several billion suns. The black hole at the centre of a galaxy known as M87 has a mass estimated at around 20 billion solar masses, and may be as large as our entire Solar System. It seems likely that the early universe, in which very large, short-lived stars were the norm, was scattered with many, many black holes, which gradually merged together over time, creating larger and larger black holes. Observations have shown that is not uncommon for two black holes to swirl around each other in a kind of cosmic dance as their gravitational fields interact. The ripples in space-time caused by two black holes orbiting around each other - typically in a three-leaved clover shape or more complex multi-pass configuration, rather than the simple orbit of an electron within an atom, and ever-smaller and faster as the two objects inevitably approach each other - can be recorded visually and even audibly. Long and short gamma ray bursts In the case of the largest events, moments after the creation of a black hole, the heat and the hugely amplified magnetic field of the collapsing star combine to focus a pair of tight beams or jets of radiation, perpendicular to the spinning plane of the accretion disk. These beams focus vast amounts of particles and energy (of the order of a billion billion times the energy output of our Sun) away from the black hole at close to the speed of light. The shock waves of this massively enegetic beam cause gamma rays to be emitted in a phenomenon known as a "gamma ray burst" or "hypernova" event (so named because its energy and brightness dwarfs even that of a supernova, by a factor of upto a hundred million times). Gamma ray bursts are by far the brightest electromagnetic events occurring in the universe, and can last from mere milliseconds to nearly an hour - a typical burst lasts a few seconds - usually followed by a longer-lived “afterglow” emitting at longer wavelengths (x-ray, ultraviolet, visible, infrared and radio waves). It is likely that collisions between neutron stars, or between a neutron star and a black hole, can also cause gamma ray bursts. Interestingly, it appears to be easier for stars with fewer heavy elements to turn hypernova and generate gamma ray bursts. That, and the fact that larger, more short-lived stars were more common earlier in the life of the universe, mean that the phenomenon of gamma ray bursts is actually rarer today than it was. Having said that, NASA's Swift Probe, launched in 2004 with a mission specifically to locate gamma ray bursts throughout the universe, is recording at least one such event each day, so these are not rare incidents. (It should be remembered that any supernovas or gamma ray bursts we observe today in galaxies, say, 9 billion light years away, actually occurred 9 billion years ago.)

In order to question you answer first we’ll discuss something about Black Hole The black hole named Cygnus X-1 formed when a large star caved in. This black hole pulls matter from the blue star beside it.  An artist's drawing shows the current view of the Milky Way galaxy. Scientific evidence shows that in the center of the Milky Way is a supermassive black hole.  This image of Sagittarius A in the center of the Milky Way galaxy was taken by the Chandra X-ray Observatory.  Sagittarius A* is the black hole at the center of the Milky Way galaxy. A black hole is a region in space where the pulling force of gravity is so strong that light is not able to escape. The strong gravity occurs because matter has been pressed into a tiny space. This compression can take place at the end of a star's life. Some black holes are a result of dying stars. Because no light can escape, black holes are invisible. However, space telescopes with special instruments can help find black holes. They can observe the behavior of material and stars that are very close to black holes. How Big Are Black Holes?Black holes can come in a range of sizes, but there are three main types of black holes. The black hole's mass and size determine what kind it is. The smallest ones are known as primordial black holes. Scientists believe this type of black hole is as small as a single atom but with the mass of a large mountain. The most common type of medium-sized black holes is called "stellar." The mass of a stellar black hole can be up to 20 times greater than the mass of the sun and can fit inside a ball with a diameter of about 10 miles. Dozens of stellar mass black holes may exist within the Milky Way galaxy. The largest black holes are called "supermassive." These black holes have masses greater than 1 million suns combined and would fit inside a ball with a diameter about the size of the solar system. Scientific evidence suggests that every large galaxy contains a supermassive black hole at its center. The supermassive black hole at the center of the Milky Way galaxy is called Sagittarius A. It has a mass equal to about 4 million suns and would fit inside a ball with a diameter about the size of the sun. How Do Black Holes Form?Primordial black holes are thought to have formed in the early universe, soon after the big bang. Stellar black holes form when the center of a very massive star collapses in upon itself. This collapse also causes a supernova, or an exploding star, that blasts part of the star into space. Scientists think supermassive black holes formed at the same time as the galaxy they are in. The size of the supermassive black hole is related to the size and mass of the galaxy it is in. If Black Holes Are "Black," How Do Scientists Know They Are There?A black hole can not be seen because of the strong gravity that is pulling all of the light into the black hole's center. However, scientists can see the effects of its strong gravity on the stars and gases around it. If a star is orbiting a certain point in space, scientists can study the star's motion to find out if it is orbiting a black hole. When a black hole and a star are orbiting close together, high-energy light is produced. Scientific instruments can see this high-energy light. A black hole's gravity can sometimes be strong enough to pull off the outer gases of the star and grow a disk around itself called the accretion disk. As gas from the accretion disk spirals into the black hole, the gas heats to very high temperatures and releases X-ray light in all directions. NASA telescopes measure the X-ray light. Astronomers use this information to learn more about the properties of a black hole. Could a Black Hole Destroy Earth?Black holes do not wander around the universe, randomly swallowing worlds. They follow the laws of gravity just like other objects in space. The orbit of a black hole would have to be very close to the solar system to affect Earth, which is not likely. If a black hole with the same mass as the sun were to replace the sun, Earth would not fall in. The black hole with the same mass as the sun would keep the same gravity as the sun. The planets would still orbit the black hole as they orbit the sun now. Will the Sun Ever Turn Into a Black Hole?The sun does not have enough mass to collapse into a black hole. In billions of years, when the sun is at the end of its life, it will become a red giant star. Then, when it has used the last of its fuel, it will throw off its outer layers and turn into a glowing ring of gas called a planetary nebula. Finally, all that will be left of the sun is a cooling white dwarf star. How Is NASA Studying Black Holes?NASA is learning about black holes using spacecraft like the Chandra X-ray Observatory, the Swift satellite and the Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope. Fermi launched in 2008 and is observing gamma rays - the most energetic form of light - in search of supermassive black holes and other astronomical phenomena. Spacecraft like these help scientists answer questions about the origin, evolution and destiny of the universe. I hope your doubt is cleared. UPVOTE

What is a Black Hole? General Relativity predicts that any mass ≥ Planck Mass (≈ 22 μg), if compressed enough to fit within its Schwartzschild Radius (rS, see below), will form a Black Hole. rS, even for quite massive objects, is rather small — e.g., for Earth's mass M⊕≈ 6×1024kg, rS≈ 9 mm — and it takes enormous forces to make such hard-to-believe compressions happen. We have to reach for the stars to find those! A star can be said to be a free-falling natural nuclear fusion reactor, the result of huge masses of hydrogen gas, collapsed and compressed by gravity to the point where internal pressure and temperature initiates nuclear fusion of hydrogen (H) to helium (He), releasing energy in the process. The “Proton-Proton Chain I” is one of several “reaction pathways” inside a star, together liberating copious amounts of energy:  The gas masses surrounding the core exert inward gravitational pressure, which tends to compress the star (decreasing volume = increasing density). This pressure is balanced — in hydrostatic equilibrium — by an outward thermal pressure resulting from the fusion reactions in the star’s core layers, which tend to expand the star, like this:  This “tug-of-war” between the outer and inner star layers continues in stages: as one fusion process depletes its available fusible material, reactions slow down, which makes gravity compress the core further (which increases pressure & temperature), initiating another fusion stage, and so on, (roughly) like this, all the way up to Fe:  When fusion processes have depleted even the material needed to fuse into iron, things get critical: So far, pressure and temperature created by the inward pressure required no other energy input to the core for fusion processes to continue. However, to fuse iron (and heavier elements) into even heavier elements, much more energy is required. Fusion reactions fizzle out, and eventually may come to a halt! As a result, gravity will “win the tug-of-war” — the star implodes (gravitationally collapses “upon itself”) in a core collapse, which may have different end results, depending on the original mass of the star: it releases huge amounts of gravitational energy, explosively ejecting the material in the star’s outer layers — some of it now fused to elements heavier than iron — into surrounding space, in the shape of dust and radiation, in a supernova explosion.  Adaptation of original image (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Explosion_and_implosion.svg) from Wikimedia Commons (User Fastfission). If the star originally had sufficient mass — the cutoff point is called Chandrasekhar’s Limit ≈ 1.4 solar masses (1 Mʘʘ ≈ 2.8×1030kg) it may collapse to a point where its remaining mass is compressed to ≤ rS for that mass, and that’s how a BH may be born. That answers your first question — a BH is a chunk of mass, so compressed that its gravity creates a spacetime distortion so severe that within its event horizon, all possible geodesics lead straight to the BH center — nothing, not even light can escape this stronghold! What Exactly is the Black Hole “Event Horizon”? An Event Horizon (EH) can be several things, but in the BH context it is synonymous with the BH Schwartzschild radius (rS). The formula for computing rS= 2GM/c2, where G = the Gravitational Constant. If all mass M of an object is compressed into a sphere with a radius = rS for that mass, it is a BH — by definition — and nothing from within the EH can ever get out of it. A BH EH is not a physical surface, it is simply the “virtual sphere” defined by the BH rS. Since nothing — not even EM radiation (i.e., light) — can escape a BH, its EH is sometimes called “the surface of no return” (for mass falling into the BH). Since not even light can “escape,” a BH is not optically visible, thus the moniker “black hole” is a double misnomer, since a BH is neither black nor a “hole.” What is “Escape Velocity”? Escape speed — a scalar, not a vector quantity — is the speed needed by a non-accelerating object in order to “escape” (“climb out of”) the gravity well of some mass M, i.e., the more massive a body is, the higher is its escape speed. The general equation, giving the escape speed for any body of mass M, is ve= (2GM/r)2, where r = distance to the body’s center of mass.  "Plot of a 2D slice of the gravitational potential in and around a uniformly dense, spherically symmetric body. The inflection points of the cross-section are at the surface of the body." (Image and caption by AllenMcC, Wikimedia Commons). Imagine a gun being fired straight up from Earth’s surface: In order for that bullet to “escape” Earth’s gravity grip, it must leave the barrel (no further acceleration given) with a speed of at least ≈ 11.2 km/s — assuming no atmospheric friction and no Earth rotation (the bullet mass does not affect the ve equation). Why is a BH ve always exactly c? Why can ve never exceed c, regardless of BH mass? This may become clear when you consider that in order to calculate ve for a BH, you need neither its mass nor the value of G (≈ 6.7×10−11N m2/kg2)! Say you have a BH of mass M (some unknown value), you have no Internet access, and you have not memorized the values G and c. No problem! BH ve = (2GM/rS)0.5, and since the term 2GM in this equation is both dividend and divisor — recall the general equation to compute rS, above — they cancel, leaving only (c2)0.5 — “the square root of c squared” — which (of course) leaves ve = c, for any and all BH M values. Is the Singularity of a “Black Hole” Tangible? The BH “singularity,” like its “Big Bang” namesake, is not a “thing,” so the answer is no. In the BH (and BB) context, the "singularity" is the result of a math error, namely division by zero: The theoretical equation computing (for example) density (ρ) of the BH, from its mass (m) per unit volume (v), is ρ = m/v. When v = 0 — at the “singularity” — we have a problem ... And a common misconception of this nonphysical situation is that the result is infinity. However, infinity is not a number! For an analysis of the “singularities” supposedly present in a BH and in the BB, see my short essay Apples & Oranges (Singularities Compared) .pdf. Is a “Black Hole” Tangible? If someone (something) gets close enough to a BH to give it a touch, that something’s a goner. For sure. So I’d say, no: a “black hole” is one of these universal intangibles! There is considerably more to all this, besides what I have briefly glossed over above. In order to understand black hole formation in a comprehensive manner, you need to understand the death of stars, more specifically - Supernova. Although supernova formation is a detailed process, I will explain it briefly. There are two broad classifications of supernovae: Type I supernova : a star gains matter from a neighbour until its mass exceeds a certain limit.Type Ia supernova do not have a Hydrogen signature in their spectra. They are generally formed from white dwarves in a binary star system. One of the stars begins to accumulate matter from its companion and when its mass exceeds the Chandrasekhar limit, the electron degeneracy pressure within it cannot sustain the white dwarf. This sets off a runaway nuclear reaction within it leading to a supernova explosion.There are also Type Ib and Ic supernovae; excluding their details here.Type II supernova : a star, whose mass exceeds a certain limit (without acquiring matter externally) runs out of fuel and collapses.For a star to explode as a type II supernova, it must be very massive - in the order of 8 - 15 solar masses). After its core runs out of Hydrogen and Helium, this is what happens:- It gets a layered structure, with lighter elements like Hydrogen towards the outer region and heavier elements like Nickel and Iron towards the interior.- When the core's mass exceeds the Chandrasekhar limit, the core collapses under its own gravity and begins to implode.- Eventually, the collapse stops and the infalling matter rebounds. This produces a highly energetic shockwave leading to a supernova explosion.Supernova explosions lead to a violent expulsion of most of the star's outer matter, leaving behind the core. What are the properties of this core determines what happens to the core and whether or not it becomes a black hole. After the collapse, the core of the star consists of neutrons - a very large mass held in a very small volume - held together by neutron degeneracy pressure (Degenerate matter) and repulsive neutron-neutron interactions caused by the strong nuclear force. However, this happens only in cores whose mass is below the Tolman–Oppenheimer–Volkoff limit (approximately 1.5 - 3 solar masses). If the mass of the core exceeds this limit, it will collapse further to form a black hole (exception is a Quark star). There are two other ways for a black hole to form: Primordial black holes during the Big Bang: Shortly after the Big Bang, densities in the universe were very high. Initial density differences in different regions can cause them them to grow under gravity leading to a gravitational collapse and creation of a black holeIt is believed that black holes can also be formed by high energy collisions. These theories are speculative and no conclusive proof is observed. (This was the reason for the worldwide scare created when the Large Hadron Collider at Cern became operational, because the experiments involved high energy collisions). These black holes would however be too small and would evaporate in about 10^-25 seconds.Also to note is the Schwarzschild radius -    the radius of an object so that if all its mass is compressed within that object, the escape speed from its surface would equal the speed of light. A neutron star (or the core left after the supernova explosion) would collapse to an object whose radius is smaller than its Schwarzschild radius forming a black hole. Please note that this is a very brief explanation of the whole process. If you are interested in all the details, start with the supernova article on Wikipedia and follow the rest of the topics from there.

Stellar Black Holes A star is massive.  The gravitational acceleration at the surface is... um, massive, too.  The star doesn't collapse under that gravity because the gravity is balanced by an outward force of radiation as the star burns its fuel.   However, one day the star runs out of fuel to burn and that radiation force disappears, leaving the star at the mercy of gravity.  After exploding as a supernova, it begins to condense.  If it is massive enough, it will overcome the atomic and nuclear forces and force the mass to inhabit less space.   The star continues to condense, as it does so the escape velocity at the surface increases because the mass of the star is staying constant, but its radius is getting smaller and smaller.   If the star is at least five times the mass of our Sun, the escape velocity will eventually be greater than the speed of light and nothing can escape.  The star will then be a black hole.  The value of "r" for a black hole formed from a star five times the mass of our Sun would be about 14 km. Supermassive Black Holes Less well understood are supermassive black holes (SBH), but the basic idea is that we aren't waiting for a star to run out of fuel.  We are using the same equation as above, but we increase the mass by taking a massive object and adding more mass to it.  This could be the collision of two massive objects or it could happen through gradual accretion, such as a collapsing cloud. The supermassive black holes at the center of many galaxies are believed to be as massive as 3 billion of our Suns.  The largest SBH found, to date, is believed to be as massive as 17 billion of our Suns. Micro Black Holes The idea of mini black holes was introduced by Stephen Hawking about 40 years ago.  He reasoned that the extremely energetic expansion of the universe immediately after the Big Bang could have squeezed small amounts of matter to incredible densities.  This could happen to any size mass above the Planck mass. VanDevender & VanDevender from Sandia National Laboratories have an interesting paper about them.  I'll put a link at the bottom. Their thought is that for small mass black holes, rather than sucking all the mass in, the mass becomes gravitationally binded, causing the mass to orbit the black hole. They define a black hole as any object smaller than its Schwarzschild radius.  They believe that space may be full of them, and that they may be the home of much of the mysterious dark matter. http://arxiv.org/pdf/1105.0265v1...

There are 7 ways Black Holes form, or at least, we think there are 7 ways. What happens to form a black hole is that enough matter (or something) collapses in on itself so that space-time is bent around it into a sphere of bent space-time. The collapsing material becomes a singularity, a single point with infinite density and all of that matter, and an Event Horizon barrier (that space-time bent into a sphere) that is the point of no return. The size of the EH is determined by the amount of mass in the singularity. Supernova: you need a star that’s at least 8–10 times the mass of the Sun. Stars greater than about 20–40 solar masses will give you a black hole; stars less than that will give you a neutron star. Neutron star merger or accretion to a black hole: you need either two neutron stars inspiraling or randomly colliding, or a neutron star siphoning mass off of a companion star to cross a threshold (around 2.5–3 solar masses) to become a black hole. Direct collapse black hole: you need enough material (gas clouds) in one place to form a star ~25 times the mass of the Sun or more, and the right circumstances to get a black hole directly (with no supernova) as a result. medium.com. Sound waves: So-called primordial black holes would have spawned soon after the big bang, when sound waves radiated throughout the seething hot ball of plasma that filled the universe. Areas where those waves are densest could have collapsed to form them … But so far there is no firm evidence for their existence. Laymen often forget that the notions of “black holes” (though the term was not coined back then; it was coined after Einstein published GR) pre-date Einstein. It just means something that is so gravitationally attractive that the velocity required to exit its field is greater than the speed of light. That is why they are black. You have three basic categories of theoretical or (perhaps) observed black holes: primordial, stellar (i.e., gravitational collapse), and relativistic-collision-based (i.e., kugelblitz). Some black holes may have been created during the Big Bang itself and exist still today. These are theoretical; they are the primordial class, and I’m not sure by which mechanism they would have formed. I separate them out because their origins may be varied, where the other two are consistent in mechanism of origin. A star is an equilibrium state between the crushing force of gravity wanting to pull the whole of the star inward to a point, and the explosive force of nuclear fusion wanting to “explode” it outward. Many stars, like our Sun, will exist for billions of years (and have already existed for billions of years) in this state of equilibrium. Very large stars live a far shorter lifetime; some only on the order of millions of years (not billions). When they exhaust their fusion fuels (i.e., those that release energy when they are fused, rather than requiring energy for the fusion process to occur), they will experience a state of disequilibrium — nothing will be pushing outward; gravity will dominate and pull everything inward. This is a cheap way of explaining what is going on; it is thought that the core is all that collapses, not the entire star; for simplicity purposes we’ll just assume it’s the whole star. So with nothing exploding outward, everything is pulled inward. At a point during the collapse, the escape velocity for anything from the collapsing object will reach the speed of light; at that point an event horizon is formed. That region of spacetime now has the characteristics basic to a black hole. It is theoretically possible to collide sufficiently relativistic particles, in an accelerator or something similar, to create an energy density in a small enough region of space to form a black hole (or micro-black hole). But this is not within our technology today. As figured by Susskind, it would take a linear accelerator the size of the diameter (or radius — I forget — on that order of magnitude) of our galaxy with a luminosity greater than anything you could imagine (brighter than our galaxy) to accelerate particles to the state they need to be in, by chance, to collide with another and form a micro-black hole. It would likely only last for a Planck time (an unimaginably short amount of time). The length of time a black hole exists is directly proportional to its mass; stellar-mass and supermassive black holes, and primordial black holes, may have the mass needed to allow them persist for any length of time requisite for you to notice them.

The star cools down in temperature and where it goes after this depends on the size of the star. This is where gravity takes over. Smaller stars become white dwarf stars which are incredibly dense. They further cool down to become black dwarf stars. The most common (though not the only one) is what is called an iron-core collapse. Lower mass stars like the Sun can only turn hydrogen into helium, and late in their life, helium into carbon. They can never get hot enough to do anything more. But massive stars can keep adding helium nuclei to heavier and heavier nuclei by using their large gravity to compress the gas in their cores to higher and higher temperatures, until they start to build up iron in their cores as the end-product of lower-mass atoms’ nuclear reactions. However, iron cannot be burned even by the most massive stars, because turning iron into anything else, instead of producing energy, produces less energy than is used up by burning it. So once an iron core starts forming it just keeps growing and growing. However, once it reaches a certain mass (which depends in part on the mass of the overall star, since that effects the force compressing the core), the core starts to collapse under the weight of the rest of the star, and in the process all the electrons in the iron atoms combine with the protons and turn the core into a sea of nothing but neutrons. This has two effects: (1) An extremely large number of neutrinos are produced by the conversion of protons to neutrons, and (2) between its own gravity and the weight of the star above its core, the iron core soon reaches a point where it is so dense that it temporarily becomes not only nearly incompressible but also opaque to neutrinos, so that the huge number of neutrinos being produced are stopped by the iron, pushing it outward and helping it maintain its size for a few instants. This doesn’t last for very long, but in that time, the material falling inward and trying to compress the iron core is suddenly met by an impenetrable “brick wall” and stops falling inward. But that doesn’t stop the material above it from continuing to fall inward, and as a result the gas just outside the iron core is suddenly compressed and heated to trillions of degrees, and every conceivable nuclear reaction that can occur in any kind of material occurs, in almost literally an instant (at a rate which adds about a hundred or two zeros to the rate of nuclear reactions in the region surrounding the core). The immense energy produced by the sudden pause in the iron core collapse and the sudden stop of the infall of the surrounding material and its subsequent nuclear combustion does two things: (1) It blows the star apart, sending a powerful shock wave outward that within a few hours obliterates the star by spreading its material far and wide into interstellar space, and in the process liberating all the light that had been trapped inside the star prior to that, which is typically several hundred thousand times as much light as the star was allowing to slowly leak out of its surface, and since such stars tend to be a million times brighter than the Sun, means that temporarily, the star can be hundreds or billions of times brighter than the Sun, and even brighter than all the rest of the stars in its galaxy put together (we call this a supernova), and (2) it exerts tremendous pressure on the iron core, and compresses it to such a small size that it is smaller than the Schwarschild Radius for an object with the iron core’s mass — that is, turning it into a black hole. A substantial portion of the material above the iron core may also fall into the black hole, and in fact it has been recently theorized that some extremely massive stars may generate so large a compressional force on the iron core that instead of blowing itself to pieces the whole star may just collapse into the black hole, along with the core (this is based on the idea that supernovae don’t seem to occur as often as we might expect, given the number of very massive stars in a galaxy — but whether that theory is in any way correct is very uncertain, so all we can be certain of is that at least some of the material outside the iron core may join it in the black hole). (Image credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech) There's something inherently fascinating about black holes. Maybe it's that they're invisible beasts lurking in space that sometimes rip passing stars in half and scatter their remains. Whatever it is, these strange cosmic objects continue to captivate scientists and laypeople alike. But where do black holes come from? How do they form, and what gives them such awesome destructive power? [Stephen Hawking's Most Far-Out Ideas About Black Holes] Before we can answer that, we have to ask an even more fundamental question: Just what is a black hole? "Basically, it's an object or a point in space where the gravitational pull is so strong that nothing can escape from it," astrophysicist Neta Bahcall, of Princeton University in New Jersey, told Live Science. Even light waves are sucked in, which is why black holes are black. These bizarre objects arise like phoenixes springing from the ashes of dead stars. When massive stars reach the ends of their lives, the hydrogen that they've been fusing into helium is nearly depleted. So, these monster stars begin burning helium, fusing the remaining atoms into even heavier elements, up until iron, whose fusion no longer provides enough energy to prop up the star's outer layers, according to Swinburne University of Technology in Australia's Centre for Astrophysics and Supercomputing. These top layers collapse inward and then explode out as a powerful and bright burst called a supernova. Yet, a small part of the star remains behind. Albert Einstein's equations of general relativity predict that if this remnant has about three times the mass of Earth's sun, the remnant star's powerful gravitational force will overwhelm everything else and the material it's made of will be crushed to an infinitely small point with infinite density, according to NASA. The known laws of physics can't actually handle such mind-bending infinities. "At some point, they break down and we don't really know what happens," Bahcall said. [8 Ways You Can See Einstein's Theory of Relativity in Real Life] If this stellar vestige is alone, a black hole will generally just sit there not doing much. But if gas and dust surround the object, that material will get sucked into the black hole's maw, creating bright bursts of light as the gas and dust heat up, swirling around like water going down a drain. The black hole will incorporate this mass into its own, allowing the object to grow, Bahcall said. If two black holes meet, the powerful gravity of each one will attract the other, and they will get closer and closer, spinning around one another. Their collective mass will shake the fabric of nearby space-time, sending out gravitational waves. In 2015, astronomers discovered such gravitational waves via the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO), Live Science previously reported. "That was the first time we could actually see black holes and confirm that they exist," Bahcall said, adding that the results were also a beautiful corroboration of Einstein's predictive equations. Scientists had found indirect evidence of black holes before, witnessing stars in the center of our Milky Way galaxy orbiting around a gigantic invisible object, Universe Today reported. How such supermassive black holes — which can have billions of times the mass of our sun — form is an outstanding question, Bahcall said. Researchers believe that these supermassive black holes were once much smaller, forming as more modest-size black holes in the earliest days of our universe. Over cosmological time, these objects absorbed gas and dust and merged with one another to grow, ending up as colossal monsters. But many of this story's details remain fuzzy, Bahcall said. Astronomers have observed objects called quasars, which glow brighter than thousands of galaxies put together and are thought to be powered by supermassive black holes consuming matter. Quasars have been seen back as far as the first billion years after the Big Bang, when our universe formed, leaving scientists to scratch their heads over how such enormous objects could form so quickly, Bahcall said. A black hole is a region of space-time exhibiting such strong gravitational effects that nothing—not even particles and electromagnetic radiation such as light—can escape from inside it. The theory of general relativity predicts that a sufficiently compact mass can deform space-time to form a black hole. The boundary of the region from which no escape is possible is called the event horizon. Although crossing the event horizon has enormous effect on the fate of the object crossing it, it appears to have no locally detectable features. In many ways a black hole acts like an ideal black body, as it reflects no light. Moreover, quantum field theory in curved space-time predicts that event horizons emit Hawking radiation, with the same spectrum as a black body of a temperature inversely proportional to its mass. This temperature is on the order of billionths of a kelvin for black holes of stellar mass, making it essentially impossible to observe. The strength of the gravitational field is measured in terms of the curvature. And because black holes are very massive and they are very small, their gravity is very strong and creates a very large curvature of space-time.  The strength of the gravitational field is measured in terms of the curvature. And because black holes are very massive and they are very small, their gravity is very strong and [creates] a very large curvature of space-time. One way to characterise the curvature is something called the Schwarzschild radius: Rs = Gn M/c^2 Where is Gn Newton's constant of gravity, M is mass of the object and c is speed of light. The Schwarzschild radius is, more or less, the size that a given object, with a given mass, should have in order for it to be a black hole. For instance, if we managed to concentrate all the mass of the Earth into a sphere of a radius of a few centimeters, then that object would be a black hole.
